dialogues.speaker: A FADED SCHOOL BOOK
dialogues.text: lying closed on an old-fashioned wooden teaching lectern. We are ANGLED DOWN so all we can see is a piece of the mec rese and the TITLE of the book (also the title of our movie)...

dialogues.speaker: "DICK AND JANE"
dialogues.text: The book miraculously opens by itself and, as a nostalgic version of "SCHOOL DAYS" PLAYS OVER, the pages quickly unfold the back story of Dick and Jane and the names and titles of the people who make this movie. The whole style of the opening should be a kind of kiddy-version of those "Book Openings'' to old MGM movies. Like this... MUSIC AND TITLES CONTINUE. We blow open to the first page where the story begins. This page is labeled, "DICK" at the bottom and the picture on the page is of a young boy of about ten sitting under a tree reading "IVANHOE." In the background is a large, comfortable house. (NOTE: All the pictures in the book are in that romanticized and nai style unique to the Dick and Jane Series. But we shall use the real childhood photos of our stars, Jane Fonda an George Segal.) Another page turns and we SEE a picture of Dick's father, a rugged but gentle, distinguished but earthy, fun but serious, neat but casual guy, standing on the front porch of the house holding a football and shouting to his son, Dick, who has. dropped his book and is looking eagerly at his father. Beneath the picture are these words... *

dialogues.speaker: FATHER. ."LOOK WHAT I HAVE."
dialogues.text: Another page blows open. The ball has been thrown and Dick is running after it. Caption...

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOK
dialogues.text: Another page turns and we SEE Dick, now in a high school football uniform and helmet, running to catch a pass. This picture is captioned... .

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: as we SEE DICK running through various stages of his life years 15 through 19. He is in constant motion; running to classes, delivering newspapers, running for class office, running in every known.sporting activity, running with hi friends after a group of giggling girls. Beneath all this is the caption... "RUN, DICK; RUN.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOK
dialogues.text: as another page blows open and we SEE a picture of a darl little girl in pigtails sitting on her pretty bed. Outsid her window stands a magnolia tree complete with a chirpin robin. | The girl is reading "IVANHOE." This picture is abeled...

dialogues.speaker: "JANE"
dialogues.text: A page turns and the next picture is of Jane's mother com in the room with a big wrapped present as Jane's eyes lig up. Jane's mother is an even more wholesome-looking perso than Dick's father. This picture is captioned... =

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE opens the gift her MOTHER has given her.. It's a pla tea set. Jane's Mother begins showing her how to set up the tea things on the bed, shoving the book aside. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Have fun, Jane. Play and have fun.

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: briefly fleshing out Jane's junior high and high school years...which seem to be one long whirl of fun. We SEE Jane dancing with a boy, trying to study in a class but succumbing to the flirting of a boy behind her, jumping up in a cheer-leader costume (great legs), taking a home- class, sleeping at a slumber party that is suddenly attac by a group of boys, etc. UNDER THESE DISSOLVES the same legend remains constant... "PLAY, JANE, PLAY.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOK
dialogues.text: Many pages blow by as MUSIC AND TITLES CONTINUE. The miraculous breeze stops at a page titled:

dialogues.speaker: GO TO COLLEGE."
dialogues.text: ABOVE THIS TITLE is an idealized picture of a college (imposing and friendly). Eager students approach this citadel of learning from different paths. Easily discern- ible are Dick and Jane, coming from different directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick's college life. _We SEE him in various classes, most of them centering on aerospace and related mathematical subjects. In the brief snatches of non-classroom life (playing ball, trying out for a play), he seems happier. BENEATH all this ACTION:

dialogues.speaker: JANE'S COLLEGE LIFE
dialogues.text: Pretty much the same as Dick, only her classes are more liberal-artsy and she seems to have a much easier time of it, getting good grades, helping others study, but goofing off really more than Dick and going out with a lot of different boys.

dialogues.text: This picture shows a very 1950's collegiate Dick and Jane bumping into each other backstage at an auditorium. The - caption reads:

dialogues.text: As a Lincoln pulls in, we can't help noticing the vast ga between cars, the lot somewhat less than half-filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Harper, young, attractive, assured, carrying a soft leather attache case, emerges from car, strides toward ‘ building. Suddenly, he stops short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In those spaces, where "Reserved" places are marked for executives, he sees a Mexican worker lazily painting out a name. Fresh white paint already obliterates two other names. The Mexican worker's name, incidently, is RAOUL. ©

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some 50 work desks, but only 15 to 20 functioning, the ot unattended, At functioning desks, black girls decked out white surgical costumes, large magnifying glasses before are working on tiny transistors. As Dick and Roger, another V.P., pass, en route.to elevat

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Christ, the body count is getting heavy around here.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Half of accounting was wiped out this morning. Structural design is taking heavy casualties. As they reach the elevator door, and it opens, drunken singing is heard from within.

dialogues.speaker: DICK -
dialogues.text: Bob...Oh, God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revealing Bob, clearly drunk, emerging from elevator, bei supported by yet another V.P., Marty.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Good luck. I've just been asked to cut back my division by forty per cent. I feel like the grim reaper. :

dialogues.speaker: MARTY -
dialogues.text: We.all feel the same’ way, but what are you going to do? After the last quarter -- BOB (interrupting) The company's on its ass. The whole aerospace industry is on its ass. Son of a bitch. I need another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ghey wander off and elevator doors shut on a perturbed Dic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretary sadly looks up as Dick strides past, into offic of Gharlie Sanford, Corporate Vice-President of Dixon Air Craft.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SANFORD'S OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: Dick comes in to discover Sanford sitting on a leather co with his coat off, his feet propped up on coffee table, a drink in hand. Charlie is a big athletic looking man, fif with a lot of silver hair. His walls are lined with frame signed photographs of astronauts, military brass, cabinet ministers. :

dialogues.speaker: SANFORD
dialogues.text: Dick...Sit down and pour yourself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Thanks, Charlie. Dick pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: SANFORD
dialogues.text: This business stinks. You know that?

dialogues.speaker: _ DICK
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To know the feeling that you've been a part of the team that tied the lace on the shoe that took that giant step for mankind. You don't get that from building a goddamn missile. It stinks. It used to be the most exciting business in the world, and now it stinks on ice.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: It's been a rough year.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It stinks.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I guess it does stink.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It stinks on ice,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On ice, Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this crap? He's referring to Dick's stack of papers, charts, etc.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: It's my plan to re-organize my department. I figure... CHARLIE (interrupting) One small step. One giant step for mankind...

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Oh I wouldn't say that. But it's not a bad plan, I ----

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know who made that step possible? We did. You and me - and Bob Kane and Marty Fields. We put Neil and whats-his-name on the fucking moon and then they gave us the shaft. It stinks.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: On ice.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Goddamn right it does. Charlie finishes his drink, pours himself another.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How's you drink? » DICK Fine, CHARLIE . Well...What do you say we talk , turkey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In response, Dick begins to arrange his papers in front o

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: - I've tried to think of cutting back in terms of cost rather than...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dick... ¢ \ (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED: . 1o.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Charlie...?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dick, I've always felt you were a guy I didn't have to bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: DICK ,
dialogues.text: I'm glad to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: In this job you have to bullshit a lot of guys, give 'em the old stroke...you know...But I've always felt I could level with you. You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can I level with you?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: _ Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I mean really level?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: ..,@harlie, you can tell me anything.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're fired. Charlie breaks up. Dick laughs too, uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I never once said it straight out like that. DICK (laughing) . Practice makes perfect. But Charlie is suddenly depressed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I shouldn't have done that. It's just that I'm sick of all the bullshit. I'm sorry. I shouldn't have...

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... you're serious? CHARLIE (hurt) Would I kid a pal?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: No jokes, Charlie. You're really firing me? Charlie tries to salvage a little of his corporate manner

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don't have to tell you. this has been a rough year for us...

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: But I haven't done a bad job. » CHARLIE You've done a helluva job. Don't let anybody tell you different. Shit, you know how I feel about you and Jane. ‘ DICK . Then why me? Why not Marty or Bob? My division's out-performed both of theirs. CHARLIE (vague) Seniority...I think that's what it was alee vores yyseniority. I'm sure that's what it was. Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it. The high point of Charlie's drunk has faded and now he is verging on the nod.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Listen, Dick, do you mind if we don't go into all this crap now? Frankly, I'ma little looped and... I've got blood on my hands...a lot of blood... . Cunningly, he now feigns sleep. Dick just stands there for a moment, glaring at him, uncertain. Finally, he gathers his papers and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosy Dick emerges into secretary's office. He pays no att } until she stops him. ° ELEANOR . Mr. Harper...I just want to say that I'm very sorry you're leaving us.

dialogues.speaker: . DICK
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Sanford tell you about the car?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: ) What car? .

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: The company car you've been using. You can retain the use of it for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Isn't that thoughtful? ELEANOR (obsequious smile) And we will continue to pay your membership in the country club until the end of the quarter, but we must have your company credit cards now, please. A beat; even as she holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Damn it, they're in my other suit. I'll bring them round tomorrow. . Then, as he turns to go, she lapses automatically into cheery Californese.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, and have a nice day.

The BARTENDER, a big, bronzed Indian, long greasy black hair, headband, is coping with a drunke salesman as Dick sits down at the bar, . DRUNK (to bartender) Screw that. You just tell me where it says in the Bible -- and I want chapter and verse, man -- that the Indians are entitled to land claims settlements? DICK . A J & B on the rocks, please. Make it a double.

dialogues.text: Did your boys invent the electric light? Or the jet engine? Shit; you still hadn't discovered the fucking wheel when we landed here.

dialogues.text: (with a sweeping gesture) Drinks on the house.

dialogues.text: Twenty-eight sixty!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As he explodes with laughter at his own foul joke, Dick, seething, digs into his pockets for the cash.

dialogues.speaker: . GOLDONI

dialogues.text: Startled

PANNING over the wreck of the garden as everything comes to an abrupt halt: the cement mixer, the tile-layers, the excavator, Everything. A sudden menacing silence enhanced by Goldoni's big intimidating presence.

dialogues.text: What did you say? ; as DICK (to Jane) Hee Tell him what you said,

dialogues.text: No. You. ‘ Jane is the first to recover,

dialogues.text: He said he was tired, Goldoni. shakes his head, he grins, admiring her cool, bu he is not to be conned,

dialogues.text: As Billy comes running up.

dialogues.text: Hey, Dad, what did you do to your car?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Not now, Billy. A dry tense pause, as Dick braces himself, fists clenched and Goldoni, all belligerence, reflects suddenly, without warning, driving a finger into a terrified Dick.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDONI
dialogues.text: What's your sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aquarian sign Goldoni wears. DICK (chancing it) Aquarius.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDONI
dialogues.text: Oh, you poor prick, I knew it. He walks away, holding his head, lips pursed, and returns despairing.

dialogues.speaker: ' GOLDONI
dialogues.text: As of yesterday, our Third House is empty. Dick whistles in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDONT
dialogues.text: It's a real ball-crusher, Jupiter has just entered our Seventh House and --- oh, shit, you might as well know --- Mars is in direct juxtaposition to Saturn.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, no. As Goldoni curses his luck --- Dick's luck --- roundly in GOLDONI . It's a bad time for us, a real bummer. I'll give you until next Wednesday. And turning away from them, he blows on his whistle again once, twice, and the men resume work. CUT To:

dialogues.text: Dick and Jane are by the hold partially dug for their lon awaited swimming pool. Excavating equipment alongside, al stacks of tiles, etc. A child's toys also on seat of the excavator ---smiling---as she watches a somewhat looped D . trying stunts on Billy's skateboard, Finally, he stroll : G over to her, joining her at poolside’, Jane refills b their glasses with wine,

dialogues.text: I can't believe it, Charlie fired you.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Charlie fired me.

dialogues.speaker: . JANE
dialogues.text: That son of a bitch. After all the years of bottom-pinching I took from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick maintains a morose silence. JANE (contin) The hell with them. You'll get a better job. No answer,

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Won't you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: You're dam right I will. A beat; Jane staring at pool. JANE (meekly) What are we going to do about paying for the pool?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Darling, there is nothing to worry about. But Jane is now prepared to make real sacrifices.

dialogues.speaker: JANE

dialogues.text: And what will the neighbors say if .they don't see steam rising off our pool on chilly nights/ fas he gropes for her, kissing her neck) Dick Harper's a loser! And I'm going to start canning things, just like my mother. ‘DICK (his advances growing more heated) I do appreciate your pioneering spirit, Calamity, and now if you'd care to mosey upstairs with me there's something in my sleeping bag I'd like to show you. JANE (kissing him) Shoot. What could that be?

dialogues.speaker: . DICK
dialogues.text: Well, it's good for lumbago, athlete's foot, headache,..and guaranteed to melt your little ole panty straps.

dialogues.text: You are talkin' dirty now! As they embrace,
